## Question 1
**According to some accounts, an early form of accounting that recorded “national” wealth was represented by:**

<form>
<input type="radio" name="q1"> Cattle<br>
<input type="radio" name="q1"> Paper currency<br>
<input type="radio" name="q1" data-correct="true"> Tally sticks<br>
<input type="radio" name="q1"> Jewellery<br>
</form>

:::callout-tip
**Correct answer:** Tally sticks  
They were used in medieval England as an accounting device to record obligations and wealth.
:::

## Question 2
**In an economy with 6 goods, the number of possible exchange ratios would be:**

<form>
<input type="radio" name="q2"> 6<br>
<input type="radio" name="q2"> 12<br>
<input type="radio" name="q2" data-correct="true"> 15<br>
<input type="radio" name="q2"> 30<br>
</form>

:::callout-tip
**Correct answer:** 15  
The number of bilateral exchange ratios is \( n(n-1)/2 \).
:::

## Question 3
**A currency based on fiat money differs from one based on commodity money by the fact that:**

<form>
<input type="radio" name="q3"> The former uses paper while the latter uses metallic coins<br>
<input type="radio" name="q3" data-correct="true">
The bearer of commodity money has a claim to an equivalent value of the commodity itself, while the bearer of fiat money has no such claim<br>
<input type="radio" name="q3"> The former is issued by a central bank while the latter is not<br>
<input type="radio" name="q3">
The former circulates as a medium of exchange only because it is universally accepted as playing this role while the latter does not require such acceptance<br>
</form>

:::callout-tip
**Correct answer:** Commodity money embodies intrinsic value; fiat money does not.
:::

## Question 4
**Which of the following properties is an *objective* criterion for something to serve as a medium of exchange?**

<form>
<input type="radio" name="q4"> Marketability<br>
<input type="radio" name="q4"> Backing by a Central Bank<br>
<input type="radio" name="q4"> Predictability of exchange value<br>
<input type="radio" name="q4" data-correct="true"> Durability<br>
</form>

:::callout-tip
**Correct answer:** Durability  
Durability is a physical property independent of beliefs or institutions.
:::

## Question 5
**Which of the following statements reflects the debate between Keynesian and Classical economists?**

<form>
<input type="radio" name="q5" data-correct="true">
The use of money as a store of value can lead to profound implications for macroeconomic stability<br>
<input type="radio" name="q5">
Every trader is willing to accept money as a means of payment precisely because every other trader is willing to accept money as a means of payment<br>
<input type="radio" name="q5">
The use of a common unit of account for all items traded in an economy makes it easier to keep track of the exchange ratios between these items<br>
<input type="radio" name="q5">
The use of money as a medium of exchange automatically makes it a store of value<br>
</form>

:::callout-tip
**Correct answer:** Keynesians emphasize money’s role as a store of value and its macroeconomic consequences.
:::
